snippet: Expelling the Islamist militants may have been the easy part of retaking Malian towns. Now French forces are focusing on a harsh mountain range where many of those militants are hiding.
abstract: Islamist militants on the run in Mali are hiding out in rugged, rocky expanse in northeast of country, which has become symbol of continued challenges facing international effort to stabilize Sahara; military officials, analysts and local fighters say expelling militants from northern towns may have been easy part of retaking Mali, and attention is being focused on Adrar des Ifoghas, one of Africa's harshest and least-known mountain ranges.

byline.original: By ADAM NOSSITER and PETER TINTI
byline.contributor: Adam Nossiter reported from Dakar, and Peter Tinti from Gao, Mali. Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington, and Scott Sayare and Steven Erlanger from Paris.

lead_paragraph: Expelling the Islamist militants may have been the easy part of retaking Malian towns. Now French forces are focusing on a harsh mountain range where many of those militants are hiding.

headline.seo: New Focus in Mali Is Finding Militants Who Have Fled Into Mountains
headline.main: Mali War Shifts as Rebels Hide in High Sahara
headline.print_headline: Mali War Shifts As Rebels Hide In High Sahara
